name: lobelia-siphilitica
wildlife-value: Its flowers are attractive to hummingbirds and butterflies.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: This plant has low resistance to damage from deer.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: Great lobelia is a clump-forming perennial which features an elongated cluster of light to dark blue, tubular, 2-lipped flowers with the three lobes of the lower lip appearing more prominent than the two lobes of the upper lip. The flowers arise from the upper leaf axils forming a dense terminal raceme atop stiff, unbranched, leafy stalks typically rising 2-3' tall. Its flowers are larger than other lobelias and have stripes on the tube portion. Blooms from July to October.
leaf-description: Great lobelia has finely-toothed, lance-shaped, light green leaves (to 5" long). The alternate, stalkless leaves are 2 to 6 inches long.
poison-symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, salivation, exhaustion and weakness, dilation of pupils, convulsions, and coma
poison-toxic-principle: Alkaloids lobelamine, lobeline, and others, plus a volatile oil
